TITLE: CEO outlook dims sharply, with more than half expecting a recession ahead, survey shows
SUMMARY: The Conference Board measure of CEO sentiment showed that 57% expect the economy to sustain a "very short, mild recession."

TITLE: Households are now spending an estimated $5,000 a year on gasoline
SUMMARY: U.S. households are now spending the equivalent of $5,000 a year on gasoline, up from $2,800 a year ago, according to Yardeni Research.

TITLE: Weekly mortgage demand from homebuyers tumbles 12%, as higher interest rates take their toll
SUMMARY: Higher mortgage interest rates are hitting homebuyer affordability hard, and that is showing up in a sharp drop in mortgage applications.

TITLE: Powell says the Fed will not hesitate to keep raising rates until inflation comes down
SUMMARY: Fed Chair Jerome Powell said he will back interest rate increases until prices start falling back toward a healthy level.

TITLE: Homebuilder sentiment falls to 2-year low on declining demand and rising costs
SUMMARY: "Housing leads the business cycle, and housing is slowing," said NAHB Chairman Jerry Konter, a builder and developer.

TITLE: Retail spending increased 0.9% in April, boosted by demand and inflation
SUMMARY: Retail sales were expected to rise 1% in April, according to Dow Jones estimates.

TITLE: California's gas average tops $6 per gallon as prices surge across the U.S.
SUMMARY: California's state average for a gallon of gas hit a record above $6.

TITLE: Fed's Waller promises to tackle inflation, says mistakes of the '70s won't be repeated
SUMMARY: Fed Governor Christopher Waller pledged that the rate-setting group wouldn't make the same mistakes on inflation that it did in the 1970s.

TITLE: April's consumer price index report expected to show inflation has already peaked
SUMMARY: April's consumer price index may show inflation has reached its height.

TITLE: Inflation outlook for consumers falls from record high, Fed survey shows
SUMMARY: Inflation expectations over the next year fell to a median 6.3% in April, a 0.3 percentage point decrease from the record high the previous month.

TITLE: Fed's Neel Kashkari confident inflation can come down, but not without some pain
SUMMARY: Minneapolis Fed President Neel Kashkari said Monday he's confident inflation will come back to normal, though he added it will take longer than he expected.

TITLE: Here's where the jobs are — in one chart
SUMMARY: Hiring in the manufacturing, transportation and health-care sectors helped the U.S. economy add more than 400,000 jobs in April.

TITLE: Payroll growth accelerated by 428,000 in April, more than expected as jobs picture stays strong
SUMMARY: Nonfarm payrolls grew by 428,000 for the month, a bit above the Dow Jones estimate of 400,000. The unemployment rate was 3.6%.

TITLE: 'Unretirement' is becoming a hot new trend in the sizzling U.S. labor market
SUMMARY: The level of workers who retired then came back a year later is running around 3.2%, just about where it was before the pandemic.

TITLE: Regulators propose first major revamp to fair housing rules since 1995
SUMMARY: The changes would tailor the Community Reinvestment Act's approach to making sure banks are not engaging in "redlining."

TITLE: Worker output fell 7.5% in the first quarter, the biggest decline since 1947
SUMMARY: Worker productivity fell to start 2022 at its fastest pace in nearly 75 years while labor costs soared.

TITLE: Fed raises rates by half a percentage point — the biggest hike in two decades — to fight inflation
SUMMARY: Wednesday's rate hike will push the federal funds rate to a range of 0.75%-1%.

TITLE: Private payrolls increased by 247,000 in April, well below the estimate, ADP says
SUMMARY: Private payrolls increased by just 247,000 for the month, well below the 390,000 Dow Jones estimate.

TITLE: Weekly mortgage demand rose for the first time since early March last week, but it won't last
SUMMARY: Total mortgage application volume rose 2.5% for the week ended April 29 compared with the previous week, according to the MBA's seasonally adjusted index.

TITLE: Job openings and the level of people quitting their jobs reached records in March
SUMMARY: Employment openings exceeded the level of available workers by 5.6 million in March while a record number of people quit their jobs.

TITLE: Home affordability is nearly the worst on record as mortgage rates spike
SUMMARY: Overheated home prices and sharply higher mortgage rates are crushing housing affordability.

TITLE: Fears of a Fed mistake grow as this week's anticipated interest rate hike looms
SUMMARY: The Federal Reserve is tasked with slowing the U.S. economy enough to control inflation but not so much that it tips into recession.

TITLE: The Federal Reserve's fight with inflation could cool the hot labor market, risking stagflation
SUMMARY: Prices are rising as the Fed winds down a historic round of stimulus. This tightening cycle could slow jobs growth as global markets ride a wave of volatility.

TITLE: Surging prices force consumers to ask: Can I live without it?
SUMMARY: Consumer spending habits are starting to shift as inflation rises and people emerge from the pandemic.

TITLE: The Fed's favorite inflation gauge rose 5.2% in March as worker pay fell further behind
SUMMARY: A measure that the Federal Reserve focuses on to gauge inflation rose at a robust pace in March.

TITLE: U.S. GDP fell at a 1.4% pace to start the year as pandemic recovery takes a hit
SUMMARY: Gross domestic product unexpectedly declined 1.4% in the first quarter, an abrupt reversal for an economy coming off its best performance since 1984.

TITLE: Fed's Mester casts doubt on the need for 'shock' interest rate hikes ahead
SUMMARY: Cleveland Fed President Loretta Mester said she's in favor of raising interest rates quickly, but not so quickly as to disrupt the economic recovery.

TITLE: Powell says taming inflation 'absolutely essential,' and a 50 basis point hike possible for May
SUMMARY: Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell on Thursday affirmed the central bank's determination to bring inflation down.

TITLE: Watch Fed Chairman Jerome Powell speak live at IMF debate
SUMMARY: Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell speaks Thursday on a panel presented by the International Monetary Fund. CNBC's Sara Eisen will moderate the talk.

TITLE: Weekly jobless claims total 184,000, just above expectations in tight labor market
SUMMARY: Initial jobless claims last week were a bit higher than expected but still reflective of a labor market where employers are loathe to fire workers.
